user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_split:
```c
static int lfs_dir_split(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_mdir_t *dir, const struct lfs_mattr *attrs, int attrcount,
        lfs_mdir_t *source, uint16_t split, uint16_t end) {
    // create tail metadata pair
    lfs_mdir_t tail;
    int err = lfs_dir_alloc(lfs, &tail);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    tail.split = dir->split;
    tail.tail[0] = dir->tail[0];
    tail.tail[1] = dir->tail[1];

    // note we don't care about LFS_OK_RELOCATED
    int res = lfs_dir_compact(lfs, &tail, attrs, attrcount, source, split, end);
    if (res < 0) {
        return res;
    }

    dir->tail[0] = tail.pair[0];
    dir->tail[1] = tail.pair[1];
    dir->split = true;

    // update root if needed
    if (lfs_pair_cmp(dir->pair, lfs->root) == 0 && split == 0) {
        lfs->root[0] = tail.pair[0];
        lfs->root[1] = tail.pair[1];
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_split:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_mdir {
    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    uint32_t rev;
    lfs_off_t off;
    uint32_t etag;
    uint16_t count;
    bool erased;
    bool split;
    lfs_block_t tail[2];
} lfs_mdir_t
...
struct lfs_mattr {
    lfs_tag_t tag;
    const void *buffer;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: int res = lfs_dir_compact(lfs, &tail, attrs, attrcount, source, split, end);
explanation: The parameter 'source' is never modified in lfs_dir_split and is passed to lfs_dir_compact only for use, so it should be investigated to determine whether it can be declared as a pointer to const (e.g. const lfs_mdir_t *source) per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Other pointer usages do not need investigation here: - 'lfs_t *lfs' is modified (lfs->root updated), so it must remain non-const. - 'lfs_mdir_t *dir' is modified (dir->tail and dir->split updated), so it must remain non-const. - 'const struct lfs_mattr *attrs' is already const-qualified. - The local 'tail' object is created and modified locally (passed by non-const &tail to alloc/compact), so non-const is appropriate. - In the provided type definitions, pointers that are read-only are already const-qualified (e.g. cfg is const, lfs_mattr.buffer is const), and other pointers (e.g. mlist->next, lookahead.buffer) represent mutable structures and likely must remain non-const. Therefore the only fragment that warrants investigation for Rule 8.13 in the shown code is the use/declaring of 'source'.
